case_vignette: A 7-day-old female presents with her parents to the pediatrician for her first well-child visit. Her mother reports that the patient is being exclusively breastfed. The patient’s mother is concerned about a rash at the nape of the patient’s neck. Her parents are not sure when the rash first developed, and the patient’s mother is concerned that the patient is having an allergic reaction to something in her breastmilk. The patient’s mother reports that the patient is urinating 6-8 times per day, and stools three times per day. The patient’s mother reports that the patient’s stools are loose, dark yellow, and “seedy,” and she denies ever seeing any streaks of blood in the patient’s diaper. The patient’s temperature is 97.9°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 60/46 mmHg, pulse is 145/min, and respirations are 30/min. On physical exam, the patient appears well-developed and well-nourished. Her anterior fontanelle is soft and flat. The patient has the physical exam finding seen in Figure A. The lesion blanches with pressure.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis of this patient’s physical exam finding?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a rash on the back of my neck.
Got it. How long have you had this rash?
I'm not sure when the rash first developed.
Understood. Have you had any fever or other symptoms along with the rash? If so, for how long?
No fever, my temperature is normal.
Do you have any other medical conditions or are you taking any medications?
No, I don't have any other medical conditions and I'm not taking any medications.
Do any members of your family have a history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases?
I don't know if there's a family history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases.
I see. Have you had any recent exposure to new skincare products, detergents, or fabrics that come into contact with the back of your neck?
I haven't been exposed to new skincare products, detergents, or fabrics.
Got it. Have you been in an area with a lot of mosquitoes or other insects recently?
I haven't been in an area with a lot of mosquitoes or other insects.
**Final Diagnosis:** Contact Dermatitis

The patient denies having a fever and their temperature is normal. They also do not have any other medical conditions and are not taking any medications. The patient is unsure if there's a family history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases and denies any exposure to new skincare products, detergents, or fabrics. They also have not been in an area with a lot of mosquitoes or other insects recently.
